Subject: RE: [junit] Testing XML output

Hi Victor, 

> What is the best practice for testing a simple database query 
> that generates several thousand moderately complex records of XML.
> Data is constantly changing, so it wouldn't make sense to 
> test against real data.
> I am thinking the tester should create a test table, populate 
> it with contrived data, and then just read the generated XML 
> against the known result.
> Is there a more elegant solution?

If there are general statements that you can make about the xml,
which shoud be true no matter what is in the database, those
statements can form the core of a test. Of course, some such
tests might not be useful. For example, assuming you are not
creating the xml with your own code, there's no point in
checking that it is valid, but you could  check for strucural
problems that could result from bad setup on your part.

One way to come up with such statements is to think back on
any issues you have seen in the past. Were some of them
observable by instpection of the xml alone, without reference
to the content of the database? Those could be tests.

Charlie
